Take your time on the 35 mile drive from Wawona Road to Glacier Point. Stop for at least 45 minutes at Sentinel Dome Parking and Washburn Point. Enjoy the views of Yosemite Valley without fighting the gridlock traffic down below. Take a picnic lunch (and take your crumbs with you.) Please, don't feed the wildlife. A morsel fed to a wild animal most often results in a change in their natural behavior which will lead to their death by starvation or extermination (if it becomes a dangerous nuisance). If you are lucky, the view to the west from Sentinel Dome area can include the Santa Cruz Mountains - about 150 miles West! On a clear day in Yosemite Valley, you can see reflections in the river and the lakes and ponds, climbers on the rocks, and hikers on the trails - bring a good pair of binoculars. Take only pictures and memories, leave only footprints.

If you only have about 2 hours to spend in Yosemite for some strange reason and you want to see what Yosemite has to over with out hiking, walking, or moving from one spot more than a few feet then you must go to Glacier Point.

Once you reach the main parking lot you have a Store, Restrooms and two viewing locations. The first is the Main one showing Half Doom and all 3 of the main Water Falls in the Valley; Vernal, Nevada and illilouette Falls.
The Second Viewing area located to the left of the first is named Glacier Point and it gives you a birds eye view of the Valley Floor and Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. There is plenty of nice scenery in Yosemite Valley, and the average tourist can get very attached to the shuttles that take you to these attractions. But...and this is a big but...you would be well advised to set aside a morning or afternoon to hop in your hot rod and drive up to Glacier Point. My trusty GPS did a great job of taking us along the winding roads that got us to the rest stop along the main highway toward Wawona. Be sure not to miss it; we got so used to winding and rocking and rolling that we almost drove past it. The road to glacier point takes off from the rest stop. It is extremely steep and winding, and you had better not have a weak heart when it comes to heights. Because of recent fires, we bulled our way up and skipped the viewpoints on the way up. Glad we did. The last 2 stops are the best. The one right before Glacier Point is absolutely awesome and we spent a lot of time there (wish I remembered the name of the viewpoint). Glacier Point is awesome with very good facilities, It is a tour bus magnet, but well worth the stop. There are few places that can rival the view from these 2 stops. Be ready to be awed. The best advice I can give for The Glacier Point stop itself is to go the full loop and park near the exit end of the gigantic parking area. When it gets busy, tour buses block you when it is time to leave, all the losers that have to stop in the middle of everything to put eyes on people that may or may not be walking to their cars, will block your way in their quest for the perfect parking spot. In fact, this place is so busy, it probably could use more parking, so that would be the one negative. Also, be advised the further down the loop you go, the less time you will spend in line waiting to use a restroom. So there; free advice from a crabby old dude with a weak bladder. Wonderful place! Take your time driving down the hill toward the main highway; the journey is more difficult downhill on this narrow road. We did not spot very many viewpoints worth pulling over for once we had been to the top of the world!

The drive up to Glacier point has some amazing view points. The road is two lane all the way but as your near the point the road gets very windy and low speed is essential. Buses etc go up and down to the point so be careful if you are driving round a hairpin bend.

At the point there is a large car park, then its a 2 minute walk to the visitor centre and from there its about 5 minutes walk to the point itself - this is an easy walk and there is a route for wheel chairs.

Once you arrive at the point the views are simply amazing.

For the really energetic there is a four mile walk down to the valley floor. We walked down a little way with no intention of doing the full walk, Most of it appears to be through woodland but there are good views through the trees.
